text: "The thing a tomato plant produces isn't a part of the plant itself, any more than the egg a chicken lays is part of the chicken, or the apple is part of the tree on which it grew," Merriam-Webster wrote.

text: A true fruit develops specifically from the mature ovary of a flowering plant following successful fertilization.
source: Why Is a Tomato a Fruit? The Botanical Explanation

text: According to Merriam-Webster, a fruit is "the usually edible reproductive body of a seed plant."   In a blog post, the dictionary explained it in simpler terms: "Any thing that grows on a plant and is the means by which that plant gets its seeds out into the world is a fruit."   That definition includes apples, tomatoes, and anything else that grows from a plant and contains seeds.
source: Here's Why a Tomato Is Actually Both a Fruit And Vegetable

text: Botanical classification is based on the structure and function of the plant, while culinary classification is based on flavor and recipe application.

text: But here’s the thing: biology doesn’t care about your taste buds.
source: Why a Tomato is a Fruit: Botanical Facts vs Kitchen Reality

text: But in their culinary uses, tomatoes are considered vegetables.Tomatoes are quite possibly one of the summer season’s most versatile produce offerings.They’re typically grouped alongside vegetables in the culinary world, but you may have also heard them referred to as fruits.This article explores whether tomatoes are fruits or vegetables and why they’re sometimes confused for one or the other.Share on Pinterest What’s the Difference Between a Fruit and a Vegetable?Nutritionally, fruits and vegetables get a lot of attention for being rich sources of vitamins, minerals and fiber (1).Although they have a lot in common, fruits and vegetables also have some distinct differences.However, these differences will vary dramatically depending on whether you’re talking to a farmer or a chef.Botanical ClassificationBotanical classification of fruits and vegetables is primarily based on the structure and function of the part of the plant in question.Fruits are formed from flowers, have seeds and assist with the plant’s reproduction process.
source: Is a Tomato a Fruit or Vegetable? - Healthline

text: Plants grown for their edible leaves include lettuce and spinach.  The flower is the edible portion of broccoli and cauliflower.  Corn is an example of a seed that is eaten.  Edible fruits include melons, apples, pears, squash, peppers, and many others. What makes this answer not so clear-cut is the fact that the term "fruit" has more than one definition. In common usage, a fruit is a plant part that is used chiefly in desserts. In contrast, a vegetable is defined as a plant part eaten with the principal part of the meal.  That plant part could be a leaf, stem, root, seed, flower, or fruit.  This makes snap beans, carrots, and spinach vegetables, while apples and cherries are fruit.  By this definition, the tomato is a vegetable because it is usually consumed during the main meal.Botanically, a fruit is defined as any plant part with seeds inside it that formed from a ripened ovary (or would have seeds inside of it if it were not a seedless variety).

text: Tomato plants are vines, largely annual and vulnerable to frost, though sometimes living longer in greenhouses.
source: Tomato - Wikipedia

text: Tomatoes are fruits that are considered vegetables by nutritionists.
source: Is a Tomato a Fruit or a Vegetable? - Britannica

text: Why a Tomato is a Fruit: Botanical Facts vs Kitchen Reality                      Spices         Home Spice Basics Global Spice Traditions Innovative Spice Pairings Spice Storage & Usage Hacks About Us             Why a Tomato is a Fruit: Botanical Facts vs Kitchen Reality  31 January 2026 By Sophie Dubois     Botanically, a tomato is a fruit because it forms from the flower of the tomato plant and contains seeds—meeting the scientific definition of a fruit.
